The Judiciary works for the American people, not for corporations or special interests. It‚Äôs well past time to build a judicial branch that represents the professional and demographic diversity of America.

Regina Rodriguez‚Äîthe daughter of a Mexican-American father and a Japanese-American mother whose family was interned during World War II‚Äîhas a remarkable breadth of courtroom experience. She'd be the first Asian-American judge on the District Court for the District of Colorado.

From a distinguished career in private practice to serving as a U.S. Magistrate Judge since 2019, Zahid Quraishi is eminently qualified to be a district court judge. Once confirmed, he will be the first American Muslim in U.S. history to serve as an Article III federal judge.

Widely praised for his impeccable qualifications and character, Julien Neals's distinguished career earned him a voice vote out of Committee in 2015 after his initial nomination to the NJ District Court. He'll be ready to take on the challenges of the District Court from day one.

Ketanji Brown Jackson is an exceptionally well-qualified jurist whose credentials and evenhanded approach to the administration of justice make her an ideal candidate for the D.C. Circuit. Her record is one of applying the law to the facts in a thoughtful, fair, impartial manner.

Candace Jackson-Akiwumi would bring much needed diversity to the Seventh Circuit, which currently has no judges of color. She has worked on civil matters in private practice & spent ten years as a federal public defender‚Äîa record that reflects a deep commitment to equal justice.

Today, I join thousands on calling for Taiwan to be admitted to the 74th World Health Assembly meeting this year and for all future meetings. It is time to give the Taiwanese people a rightful voice. #LetTaiwanHelp
